steps.title: Multiply the numerator of the left fraction by the denominator of the right fraction.
steps.content: Multiply the numerator of the left fraction by the denominator of the right fraction. The numerator is the top number in a fraction, and the denominator is at the bottom. Let's say you're working with the equation 2 / x = 10 / 13 {\displaystyle 2/x=10/13} . You would then multiply the left numerator 2 by the right denominator 13. 2 ∗ 13 = 26 {\displaystyle 2*13=26} . Jia reminds us that you can only cross-multiply 2 fractions if there’s an equals sign between them. If they’re on the same side of the equals sign, you can’t cross-multiply them.

steps.title: Multiply the numerator of the right fraction by the denominator of the left fraction.
steps.content: Multiply the numerator of the right fraction by the denominator of the left fraction. Now multiply 10 (the right numerator) by x (the left denominator). x ∗ 10 = 10 x {\displaystyle x*10=10x} . It doesn’t really matter which pair of numerators and denominators you start multiplying first as long as you multiply both numerators by the denominators diagonal from them. [1] X Research source Another way to think of cross-multiplication is by using this formula: if you have the equation a / b = c / d {\displaystyle a/b=c/d} , you would multiply them out to get the equation a d = c b {\displaystyle ad=cb} .

steps.title: Set the two products equal to each other.
steps.content: Set the two products equal to each other. Set 26 equal to 10x, written as 26 = 10 x {\displaystyle 26=10x} . Since the two products are equal to one another, it doesn’t matter which number goes on which side. So both 26 = 10 x {\displaystyle 26=10x} and 10 x = 26 {\displaystyle 10x=26} are acceptable ways to write your equation. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Solve for the variable x.
steps.content: Solve for the variable x. Start by finding the greatest common factor between 26 and 10x. This is the largest number that divides exactly into both numbers. In this case, since both 26 and 10x are even numbers, they can both be divided by 2; 26 / 2 = 13 {\displaystyle 26/2=13} and 10 / 2 = 5 {\displaystyle 10/2=5} . You're left with 13 = 5 x {\displaystyle 13=5x} . Then, to get x by itself and find its value, divide both sides of the equation by 5. So, 13 / 5 = 5 x / 5 {\displaystyle 13/5=5x/5} , or 13 / 5 = x {\displaystyle 13/5=x} . [3] X Research source If you'd like the convert the fraction to a decimal , start by dividing both sides of the equation by 10 to get 26 / 10 = 10 x / 10 {\displaystyle 26/10=10x/10} , or 2.6 = x {\displaystyle 2.6=x} .

steps.title: Multiply the numerator of the left fraction by the denominator of the right fraction.
steps.content: Multiply the numerator of the left fraction by the denominator of the right fraction. Let's say you're working with the following equation: ( x + 3 ) / 2 = ( x + 1 ) / 4 {\displaystyle (x+3)/2=(x+1)/4} . Multiply (x + 3) by 4 to get 4 ( x + 3 ) {\displaystyle 4(x+3)} . Then, distribute the 4 to get 4 x + 12 {\displaystyle 4x+12} . [4] X Research source To distribute the 4 into the equation (x + 3), multiply each part of the equation by 4. So that would be ( 4 ∗ x ) + ( 4 ∗ 3 ) = 4 x + 12 {\displaystyle (4*x)+(4*3)=4x+12} .

steps.title: Multiply the numerator of the right fraction by the denominator of the left fraction.
steps.content: Multiply the numerator of the right fraction by the denominator of the left fraction. Repeat the process using the remaining numerator and denominator. ( x + 1 ) ∗ 2 = 2 ( x + 1 ) {\displaystyle (x+1)*2=2(x+1)} . Distribute the 2 to get 2 x + 2 {\displaystyle 2x+2} [5] X Research source

steps.title: Set the two products equal to each other and combine the like terms.
steps.content: Set the two products equal to each other and combine the like terms. Now, you'll have 4 x + 12 = 2 x + 2 {\displaystyle 4x+12=2x+2} . Combine the x terms with each other on one side of the equation and the constants (the numbers without x) on the other side. [6] X Research source Combine 4x and 2x by subtracting 2x from both sides. Subtracting 2x from 2x on the right side will leave you with 0. On the left side, 4 x − 2 x = 2 x {\displaystyle 4x-2x=2x} , so 2x remains on the left-hand side of the equal sign. 2 x + 12 = 2 {\displaystyle 2x+12=2} Then, combine 12 and 2 by subtracting 12 from both sides of the equation so that 2x is left by itself. Subtract 12 from 12 on the left to get 0, and subtract 12 from 2 on the right side to get -10 (since 2 − 12 = − 10 {\displaystyle 2-12=-10} ). You're left with 2 x = − 10 {\displaystyle 2x=-10} .

steps.title: Solve for x by dividing each side by 2.
steps.content: Solve for x by dividing each side by 2. This would be 2 x / 2 = − 10 / 2 {\displaystyle 2x/2=-10/2} , which yields x = − 5 {\displaystyle x=-5} . Go back and check your work by plugging in -5 for x in the original equation to make sure that both sides of the equation are equal. This would look like: [7] X Research source ( − 5 + 3 ) / 2 = ( − 5 + 1 ) / 4 {\displaystyle (-5+3)/2=(-5+1)/4} , which simplifies to − 1 = − 1 {\displaystyle -1=-1} . Since this equation is true, it’s confirmed that x’s value is -5.

steps.title: Multiply the numerator of the left fraction by the denominator of the right fraction.
steps.content: Multiply the numerator of the left fraction by the denominator of the right fraction. Cross multiplication can be used as a shortcut to see if two fractions are equal, or “proportional.” Let’s say we have the fractions 24 / 100 {\displaystyle 24/100} and 12 / 50 {\displaystyle 12/50} . To start, multiply the numerator of the first fraction by the denominator of the second fraction. Remember that the numerator is the top number, and the denominator is the bottom number. This gives us 24 ∗ 50 = 1 , 200 {\displaystyle 24*50=1,200} Alternatively, multiply the denominators together, then multiply the numerator of each fraction by the denominator of the other fraction, and see if the products are the same.

steps.title: Multiply the numerator of the right fraction by the denominator of the left fraction.
steps.content: Multiply the numerator of the right fraction by the denominator of the left fraction. Now, we cross multiply the other parts of the fractions. Multiply the numerator of the second fraction by the denominator of the first fraction. [8] X Research source This gives us 12 ∗ 100 = 1 , 200 {\displaystyle 12*100=1,200}

steps.title: Compare the two products to see if they’re equal.
steps.content: Compare the two products to see if they’re equal. Now, look at the two products we’re left with. 1,200 is equal to 1,200, so we can say that 24 / 100 {\displaystyle 24/100} and 12 / 50 {\displaystyle 12/50} are proportional and have equal values. [9] X Research source If they weren’t the same number, the fractions wouldn’t be proportional.

steps.title: Identify the bigger fraction if the products aren’t equal.
steps.content: Identify the bigger fraction if the products aren’t equal. When comparing the products, remember that the product belongs to the fraction whose numerator was multiplied. If that fraction’s product is larger than the other when you compare them with cross multiplication, then we can say the value of that fraction is more than the other fraction. [10] X Research source For example, if we were comparing the fractions 3 / 6 {\displaystyle 3/6} and 6 / 10 {\displaystyle 6/10} , then we’d cross multiply like this: 3 ∗ 10 = 30 {\displaystyle 3*10=30} and 6 ∗ 6 = 36 {\displaystyle 6*6=36} . In this case, since 36 is larger than 30, and since the 36 product belongs to the fraction with 6 in the numerator, we can say that 6 / 10 {\displaystyle 6/10} is greater than 3 / 6 {\displaystyle 3/6} .

steps.title: Cross multiplying works because it’s a quick way to find common denominators.
steps.content: Cross multiplying works because it’s a quick way to find common denominators. When we compare two fractions with different denominators, we usually need to find a common denominator so that we’re looking at fractions that share the same number of total parts (for example, 2 / 5 {\displaystyle 2/5} has fewer total parts than 2 / 10 {\displaystyle 2/10} since 5 is less than 10). [11] X Research source By cross multiplying, we’re basically doing the same process as finding a common denominator , except we’re only looking at the numerators of the resulting fractions.

steps.title: Example:
steps.content: Example: Say we wanted to find a common denominator between 2 / 5 {\displaystyle 2/5} and 2 / 10 {\displaystyle 2/10} . First, we multiply the denominators by each other ( 5 ∗ 10 {\displaystyle 5*10} ) to get a common denominator of 50. Then, to make sure that each fraction still has the same value, we multiply the numerator of each fraction by whatever number we multiply the denominator by. So, multiply 2 ∗ 10 {\displaystyle 2*10} and 2 ∗ 5 {\displaystyle 2*5} to get the fractions 20 / 50 {\displaystyle 20/50} and 10 / 50 {\displaystyle 10/50} , which are much easier to compare. Notice how if we were simply to cross multiply the original fractions ( 2 / 5 {\displaystyle 2/5} and 2 / 10 {\displaystyle 2/10} ), we’d be doing the same operation as the step above, and looking only at the final numerators, 20 and 10. That’s cross multiplication!
